items.title: nested BoundConfigs don't work
items.body:
If you have nested `BoundConfigs`, then it just throws `KeyErrors` because of the way the nesting and `NamespaceConfigs` work:

```
from everett.component import RequiredConfigMixin, ConfigOptions
from everett.manager import ConfigManager


class Foo(RequiredConfigMixin):
    required_config = ConfigOptions()
    required_config.add_option('option1', default='')


class Bar(RequiredConfigMixin):
    required_config = ConfigOptions()
    required_config.add_option('option2', default='')


config = ConfigManager.basic_config()
config = config.with_options(Foo)
config = config.with_options(Bar)

config('option2')
```

What's going on is that 'option2' *is* a valid option for `Bar`, so it passes that test, but then it calls `self.config()` on the `self.config` which then tries to retrieve the key on `Foo` and then that throws the `KeyError`. It's designed this way so that it can accumulate namespace parts, but that doesn't work right with options.

This bug covers fixing the nested-options issue. I think what should happen is that `with_namespace` and `with_options` should unwrap a `BoundOption` if possible.

items.title: allow component options to have additional parameters
items.body:
It might be nice to allow defining options with additional parameters that Everett itself doesn't use, but which are used by the application. For example, if I wanted to log all configuration values, except for secrets, I might want to tag all secret options with `secret=True`.

Seems like it makes sense to do this generally. Maybe something like this:

```
class Component(RequiredConfigMixin):
    required_config = ConfigOptions()
    required_config.add_option(
        'some_secret',
        secret=True,
    )
    required_config.add_option(
        'not_secret',
        secret=False,
    )
    required_config.add_option(
        'also_not_secret',
    )

    def __init__(self, config):
        self.config = config.with_options(self)
```

And then it'd be accessed like this:

```
config = ConfigManager.basic_config()
comp = Component(config)
for namespace, key, value, opt in comp.get_runtime_config():
    if not opt.meta.get('secret', False):
        print('%s_%s=%s' % (namespace, key, value))
```

That seems really helpful for printing configuration securely. It'd help with grouping options, too. Might have other uses.

This issue covers implementing that.

items.title: add case to autoconf
items.body:
Some projects encourage configuration to be done in OS environment variables or env files. In this case, the configuration keys are all uppercased like `NAMESPACE_KEY`.

Some projects encourage configuration to be done with INI files. In this case, configuration keys are more naturally expressed as lowercased like:

```
[namespace]
key=foo
```

I think it's prudent for the documentation to reflect the project's preferences.

As such, I want to add a `:case:` argument with options `upper`, `lower` and default to `lower`.

items.title: add namespace to autconf
items.body:
Some projects have components that only exist in one namespace.

For example, you might have a website that sends data to S3 and have a component with configuration to make that easier. In this particular example, there's only one of these components, so the namespace is always the same.

There are a couple of ways to do this:

1. have really long configuration keys like `AWS_S3_ACCESS_KEY` and refer to that everywhere
2. have a namespace `AWS_S3` and the key `ACCESS_KEY` in the code

In the latter case, you'd want the convenience of shorter less redundant configuration keys, but want the documentation to reflect the whole name.

Towards that end, we should add something like:

```
.. autoconfig:: some.Component
   :namespace: namespace
   ...
```

And then that namespace would be prepended to all the keys.

items.title: add pointer to docs for configuration errors
items.body:
Right now, if there's a configuration error, you get something like this:

```
ConfigurationError: USERNAME (healthcheck) requires a value parseable by <type 'str'>
```

(The formatting is better, but the gist is the same.)

That's great, but it'd be even more helpful if it included help text or a link or something.

Configuration options for components have help text. We could include that. It might get messy if the help text is large and formatted. Another possibility is to tag a configuration manager with a help url which always gets spit out on configuration errors.

For now, I'm inclined to do the latter. Maybe generalize it so that the configuration manager has a `support_text` field where you could put urls or contact information or whatever.

items.title: traverse a component tree and retrieve configuration with namespaces
items.body:
I've had a couple of cases where it's super helpful to be able to print out the current configuration being used for a component tree.

Some things about this.

**Codifying that `self.config` is the config.** In order to print the config for a tree, we have to know where in the component instance the config is. I've been stashing it in the `config` attribute. If there are multiple standards, this doesn't work. Maybe we can specify the attributes the config should be found in?

**Dealing with namespaces and subcomponents.** To traverse a tree of components, we need to know the branches. I thought about codifying that in the configuration options, but that's too inflexible and causes problems where you might have one component that gets instantiated as multiple sources.

Thus, I think we should have a method that returns the runtime configuration as part of `RequiredConfigMixin`. Then we can override that to further traverse other parts of the tree. Something like this:

```
class Foo(RequiredConfigMixin):
    required_config = ConfigOptions()
    required_config.add_option(
        'source',
        default='path.to.class',
        parser=parse_class,
    )

    def get_runtime_config(self, namespace):
        return (
            super().print_config(namespace) +
            self.config('source')(namespace + ['priority_source']) +
            self.config('source')(namespace + ['normal_source'])
        )
```

That returns a list of `(namespace, key, val)` tuples. We can then print that or whatever we want to do with it.

items.title: exceptions raised from parsers should get converted to ConfigurationErrors
items.body:
Right now, parsers raise all kinds of errors which bubble up to the application code that's trying to pull a configuration key. That means that the exception that gets generated is missing a lot of context and it's not clear that the error is probably a configuration error and what the user can do to figure it out.

Instead of doing that, when a parser throws an exception, the exception should get wrapped in a ConfigurationError with a more helpful error message that includes the key and namespace. Then a user can see that and have a much better idea of what to do.

For example, this is useless:

```
web_1          | ValueError: logging level must be one of "DEBUG", "INFO", "WARNING", "ERROR", "CRITICAL"
```

I have no idea the problem is with the value of the configuration variable titled "LOGGING_LEVEL". (That's technically not true. I wrote Antenna, so I know exactly what the problem is.)

This is better:

```
ConfigurationError: USERNAME (healthcheck) requires a value parseable by <type 'str'>
```

Though we should fix the syntax a bit.

items.title: autoconfig argument for specifing attribute for content
items.body:
When doing:

```
.. autoconfig: some.Class
   :show-docstring:
```

it gets a bit awkward because the docstring for `some.Class` now needs to be user focused and not developer focused. These two groups of people are not the same. Documentation geared at developers and thus about how to use the class in code is not the same as documentation geared at users and thus about how to use and configure the class.

This is problematic.

I have a couple of ideas on how to fix it:

1. specify a way to denote sections like "this is for users" and "this is for developers" and then only the user-focused part of the docstring is used by autoconfig
2. add an argument or maybe even adjust `:show-docstring:` to specify a different attribute to look at other than the docstring to use

Of the two, item 2 seems way easier to use and think about. Maybe we change it from `:show-docstring:` to `:show-content:` and have it take a parameter which defaults to `__doc__`.

items.title: handle multiple configuration locations
items.body:
If we have a component that uses access credentials, it'd be nice to have two of that component share the access credentials in some kind of common namespace in the configuration rather than having to specify the access credentials in configuration twice.

For example:

```
COMMON_S3_ACCESS_KEY=asdf
CRASHSTORAGE_CLASS=antenna.external.s3.crashstorage.S3CrashStorage
```

Then:

```
class S3CrashStorage(RequiredConfigMixin):
    required_config = ConfigOptions()
    required_config.add_option(
        's3_access_key',
        look_also='common_s3_access_key',
        doc='AWS S3 access key'
    )
```

Or something like that.

configman uses `reference_value_from`, but that's a long name and I don't find it particularly explanatory.

What I want it to do is "Look for this key in this namespace and if it's not there, then check these other places in specified order. If it's in none of those places, then check the default."

This issue covers that.

items.title: config manager and friends should be able to tell you the namespace
items.body:
The config manager and friends should be able to tell you the current namespace.

For example:

```
config = ConfigManager([])

foo_config = config.with_namespace('foo')
```

It'd help to be able to call `foo_config.namespace` and have it return something like `['foo']`. That makes it easier to have related components share a namespace.

items.title: easier way to generate ConfigManager with a dict of configuration
items.body:
When writing tests, I find myself needing to generate a `ConfigManager` with a given configuration specified in a dict.

I think maybe adding a `.from_dict(dict)` would be helpful. Something like this:

```
from everett.manager import ConfigManager

config = ConfigManager.from_dict({
    'BASEDIR': '/tmp/foo',
    'DEBUG': 'true'
})
```

It'd be shorthand for this:

```
from everett.manager import ConfigManager, ConfigDictEnv

config = ConfigManager([
    ConfigDictEnv({
        'BASEDIR': '/tmp/foo',
        'DEBUG': 'true'
    })
])
```

items.title: .with_options() prevents pulling config from top-level
items.body:
Say we had a `DEBUG` configuration option that's defined for the entire application. The problem with `.with_options()` is that it constrains the configuration for a component to a specific namespace preventing it from looking at other parts of the configuration. Thus there's no way for a component to look at an app-scoped `DEBUG` configuration option.

This issue covers mulling over that because that kind of sucks for a large number of use cases: debug flags, logging, etc.

Maybe the solution is for the app to pull these configuration and pass it along in the `__init__`?

items.title: redo ini handling
items.body:
Right now, the `ConfigIniEnv` has a problem where it can't handle nested namespaces because it thinks of INI files as one-level deep. I'd like to fix that or think about it more.

Further, it's the only env that's case-sensitive regarding keys and namespaces. I'd like to fix that, too.

Maybe we should parse the whole file and convert it into a dict so then it matches the other envs?

items.title: figure out how to use config() in a DRY way without screwing up config override
items.body:
Say you have an app where you're doing a lot of things based on some `DEBUG` variable. You have a couple of options for implementation:
1. you could cache the value of `config('DEBUG', parser=bool)`, but that potentially screws up using config override in the tests
2. you could write `config('DEBUG', parser=bool)` over and over again, but that's awful for a variety of reasons

@ErikRose dislikes defining the types at call time, too, for similar reasons to the above.

This issue covers figuring out a better way to do this.

items.body:
These would be files of the format used by `foreman` and other Heroku-like things:

```
STUFF=whatnot
THINGS=dude
```

These can also, for example, be [pulled down from app configurations in Deis](http://docs.deis.io/en/latest/using_deis/config-application/#configure-the-application) and pushed back again.

items.title: should raise_error be renamed?
should configinienv look at multiple ini files or just one?
items.body:
Currently, the ConfigIniEnv uses the first path that exists in the list of specified possible paths.

We could change it so that it uses all the existing ini files and searches through them in the order specified. This would allow you to do something like have common configuration in one file and then deviation configuration for specific environments (e.g. prod and stage) in separate files.

It's probably not hard to support, but it's not clear the use case is super compelling and can't be handled in other ways.

Needs some thought and experimentation.
